name: Tokoname Kyusu Teapot
description: A handcrafted side-handle teapot from the Tokoname region of Aichi prefecture. The unglazed clay naturally enhances the flavor of green tea, becoming smoother and richer with each use. Each piece carries subtle variations — marks of the potter's hand and the kiln's breath.

name: Mashiko-yaki Rice Bowl Set
description: A set of four rice bowls in the distinctive Mashiko style — warm earth tones, thick glaze, and a comforting weight in the hand. The rustic stoneware embodies the mingei folk craft philosophy that beauty lives in everyday objects.

name: Bizen-yaki Sake Cup Pair
description: A pair of wood-fired sake cups from one of Japan's Six Ancient Kilns. Bizen ware uses no glaze — the surface patterns emerge from ash falling on the clay during the two-week firing. No two pieces are ever alike.

name: Arita Porcelain Tea Cup
description: A delicate tea cup in the classic Arita blue-and-white tradition. Hand-painted with graceful brush strokes depicting seasonal flora, this porcelain piece balances centuries of tradition with refined elegance.

name: Shigaraki Flower Vase
description: A sculptural flower vase with the characteristic natural ash glaze of Shigaraki ware. The rough texture and warm tones evoke the landscape of Shiga's mountains. Perfectly imperfect — a vessel that honors both the flower and the empty space around it.

name: Hasami Porcelain Plate Set
nameJp: 波佐見焼プレートセット
description: A set of four dinner plates in clean, contemporary lines. Hasami porcelain bridges 400 years of tradition with modern design sensibility — stackable, durable, and quietly beautiful on any table.

name: Tosa Hocho Santoku Knife
description: A hand-forged santoku knife from the blacksmiths of Kochi. The blade is Aogami (Blue Steel) — extraordinarily sharp with excellent edge retention. The magnolia wood handle sits naturally in the hand. A tool made to last generations.

name: Hinoki Cypress Cutting Board
description: A cutting board carved from Yoshino hinoki cypress — naturally antibacterial, gentle on knife edges, and beautifully fragrant. The wood's fine grain and pale color darken gracefully with use, developing a patina that tells the story of meals prepared.

name: Nanbu Tetsubin Cast Iron Kettle
description: A cast iron kettle in the Nanbu tradition of Iwate. The arare (hailstone) pattern across its surface is both decorative and functional — it increases surface area, helping the kettle heat water more evenly. Iron from the kettle subtly enriches the water.

name: Iga-yaki Donabe Clay Pot
description: A traditional clay pot for the table — ideal for hot pot, rice, and slow-simmered soups. The porous Iga clay retains heat beautifully and releases far-infrared rays that enhance the umami of ingredients. Cooking and serving in one vessel, as it has been done for centuries.

name: Kiso Lacquerware Chopstick Set
description: A set of five pairs of chopsticks finished in traditional urushi lacquer. Each pair features a different subtle pattern — a nod to the five elements. The lacquer is applied in dozens of thin layers, creating a surface that is both durable and exquisitely smooth.

name: Seto Ceramic Mortar (Suribachi)
description: A traditional grinding bowl with fine grooves carved by hand into the interior. Used for grinding sesame seeds, making dressings, and preparing miso-based sauces. The Seto potters have been refining this form for over 800 years — each groove is a line of practiced precision.
